awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Microparticle/tephra analysis of the WAIS Divide ice core
awd_abstract_narration:
Kreutz/0636740
Dunbar/0636767

This award supports a project to perform continuous microparticle concentration and size distribution measurements (using coulter counter and state-of-the-art laser detector methods), analysis of biologically relevant trace elements associated with microparticles (Fe, Zn, Co, Cd, Cu), and tephra measurements on the WAIS Divide ice core. This initial three-year project includes analysis of ice core spanning the instrumental (~1850-present) to mid- Holocene (~5000 years BP) period, with sample resolution ranging from subannual to decadal.   The intellectual merit of the project is that it will help in establishing the relationships among climate, atmospheric aerosols from terrestrial and volcanic sources, ocean biogeochemistry, and greenhouse gases on several timescales which remain a fundamental problem in paleoclimatology.  The atmospheric mineral dust plays an important but uncertain role in direct radiative forcing, and the microparticle datasets produced in this project will allow us to examine changes in South Pacific aerosol loading, atmospheric dynamics, and dust source area climate. The phasing of changes in aerosol properties within Antarctica, throughout the Southern Hemisphere, and globally is unclear, largely due to the limited number of annually dated records extending into the glacial period and the lack of a
tephra framework to correlate records.  The broader impacts of the proposed research are an interdisciplinary approach to climate science problems, and will contribute to several WAIS Divide science themes as well as the broader paleoclimate and oceanographic communities. Because the research topics have a large and direct societal relevance, the project will form a centerpiece of various outreach efforts at UMaine and NMT including institution websites, public speaking, local K-12 school interaction, media interviews and news releases, and popular literature. At least one PhD student and one MS student will be directly supported by this project, including fieldwork, core processing, laboratory analysis, and data interpretation/publication. We expect that one graduate student per year will apply for a core handler/assistant driller position through the WAIS Divide Science Coordination Office, and that undergraduate student involvement will result in several Capstone experience projects (a UMaine graduation requirement). Data and ideas generated from the project will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate course curricula at both institutions.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Insoluble mineral aerosols (hereafter termed ‘dust’ or ‘microparticles’) are an important but poorly understood component of Earth’s climate system.  Aerosols act as a negative forcing on the radiative balance of the atmosphere, through direct (absorption and scattering of incoming solar radiation) and indirect (e.g., cloud albedo) effects; mineral aerosols also provide a critical source of iron (Fe) and other trace nutrients to remote regions of the world’s oceans. Aerosol Fe fertilization of marine primary producers in Fe-limited waters can impact global climate by increasing carbon export to the deep ocean and drawing down atmospheric CO2, a process which may act as an important climate feedback.  In addition, dust is a tracer of atmospheric circulation, as it gets entrained from continental sources in the southern hemisphere and transported to Antarctica, where it is deposited on the ice sheets. Because of the dynamic and nonlinear response of dust emissions to climate forcing, ice core records of dust deposition can be used to understand the timing and mechanisms of paleoclimatic changes. Existing microparticle and dust proxy records from Antarctica have provided valuable insights into glacial/interglacial changes in dust deposition and their causes, as well as recent changes due to anthropogenic forcing; however, knowledge of how dust deposition responds to climate forcings during the preindustrial late Holocene (i.e., the last 2000 years) is hampered by a lack of high resolution microparticle data.

   The overall goal of this project was to develop a new late Holocene record of dust deposition from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide deep ice core. We analyzed microparticle concentration and size distribution and trace elemental composition in the upper 577 meters (the last 2400 years) of the core. The past two millennia are an important time period for evaluating climatic changes, as they encompass both the industrial period and a significant length of time prior to anthropogenic fossil fuel burning that is both long enough to evaluate climate variability on decadal-to-centennial timescales and short enough that the boundary conditions of the climate system as a whole are unlikely to have changed. Our project reconstructed atmospheric dust deposition over the past 2400 years and addressed the following questions:

 1. What is the provenance (i.e., geographic source) of microparticles deposited in West Antarctica? Based on dust geochemistry, our results suggest that both South America and Australia/New Zealand contribute dust to West Antarctica in nearly equal amounts;

 2. What drives the seasonality of microparticle deposition in West Antarctica?  Our results show that dust is deposited primary during the austral spring in West Antarctica, suggesting that atmospheric transport strength plays a dominant role;

 3. How have particle size distribution and concentration changed through time in the WAIS Divide ice core and what do these parameters indicate about climatic changes during the late Holocene?  Our results indicate that dust changes in West Antarctica are driven primarily by periodic atmospheric pressure differences such as the Southern Annular Mode (SAM).   However, there is a clear increase in dust deposition during and after the mid-1980’s, which may be related to anthropogenic activity; 

4. What drives changes in the relative proportions of soluble, labile, and particulate aerosol Fe deposited at WAIS Divide through time? We found that changes in aerosol Fe concentrations are related to particle size distribution.  Fe in smaller particles is more labile, suggesting that biologically available Fe deposition may be linked to atmospheric processes.

 

Intellectual merit and broader impacts.  The new high-resolution microparticle size distribution and composition record produced through this project provides an unprecedented opportunity for identifying the dominant controls on atmospheric dust and aerosol Fe deposition in West Antarctica on interannual to multidecadal timescales over the past 2400 years.  Our research contributes to the scientific understanding of the variability of past atmospheric and environmental conditions and the controls on atmospheric CO2 concentrations and dust-Fe biogeochemistry and will be of value to the paleoceanographic and climate modeling communities. The broader impacts of this project include the support of graduate student research, resulting directly in two UMaine PhD dissertations (Bess Koffman and Daniel Breton), field and laboratory opportunities for graduate students (Bess Koffman and Dominic Winski), laboratory experience for several UMaine undergraduates (Eliza Kane, Shelly Griffin, Robert Strauss, Brittany Gilman, Robert Harrington), and supported student participation and presentations at several UMaine, regional, national, and international meetings.  In addition, the PI has used the project and data produced as part of it in undergraduate courses (ERS200: Earth Systems, and ERS201: Global Environmental Change), as well as in several outreach efforts in local K-12 schools and other venues (e.g., GE Conversations from Antarctica).  PhD student Koffman has likewise initiated several outreach efforts fostering participation of women in science.
